    • Method Detail

      • loadWords

        public static void loadWords​(java.lang.String fileName)
        Given the name of a text file, loads the words contained in that file into the dict data structure. You should assume that if the file exists, it contains only words made up of upper- and/or lowercase letters separated by the default delimiter characters (e.g., blank space, newline character, etc.). In the end, dict may only contain words in all lowercase letters with no duplicates. If the file does not exist, a clear message must be printed on the terminal before terminating the program. Does NOT send any output to the terminal if the input file exists.
        Parameters:
        fileName - name of the text file of words

      • findNeighbors

        public static void findNeighbors​(java.lang.String word)
        Given a word in dict, insert an entry into the neighbors data structure with this word as the key and the non-empty, alphabetized list of all of the word's neighbors as the value, where a neighbor of a word w is any other word in dict that is obtained by replacing exactly (any) one letter in w by another letter. Does not modify neighbors if the given word has no neighbors in dict. Does NOT send any output to the terminal.
        Parameters:
        word - the word whose neighbors you must determine and store in neighbors

      • findAllNeighbors

        public static void findAllNeighbors()
        Populates the neighbors data structure with an entry for each one of the words in dict whose neighbors list is not empty. Does NOT send any output to the terminal.

      • printAllNeighbors

        public static void printAllNeighbors()
        Sends the contents of the neighbors data structure to the terminal. The required format of this output is described in the handout for this assignment.

      • testMe

        public static void testMe()

      • findSequence

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> findSequence​(java.lang.String start,
                                                                 java.lang.String finish)
        Returns a sequence connecting the two given words, where a sequence is a list of words with each word (except the first one) being a neighbor of the preceding word; or returns null if no such sequence exists (based on the dictionary used). Does NOT send any output to the terminal.
        Parameters:
        start - the word that must appear first in the sequence
        finish - the word that must appear last in the sequence For full credit, your method must implement the following algorithm: + you must use a basic (i.e., FIFO) queue, called q, containing ArrayList instances; each array list will be a partial sequence starting with the start word + initialize q to contain a single ArrayList with start as its only element + you will implement a loop that terminates when the first sequence ending in the finish word is about to be added to q or when q is empty (in the latter case, the method must return null). + during each iteration, you must: + dequeue the first element (i.e., ArrayList) of q; call this element 'current' + find the list of neighbors of current's last element + if one of them is the finish word, return current with this word added at the end + if this list is empty, end the iteration since there is no way to extend the current partial sequence + otherwise, for each neighbor n in the list: + make a copy of current and add n at the end of this copy + enqueue the resulting ArrayList into q This method may ONLY use the Queue (not Deque, etc.) methods that do NOT throw any exceptions. Sample outputs for this method are provided in the handout for this assignment.

      • main

        public static void main​(java.lang.String[] args)
        Driver code, which you may NOT modify. Usage: java A5 neighbors or java A5
